Primer préstamo:

http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=27118&_tpos=1&_tpg=1

Apolonia pertenece al Banco Comunal Primavera hace 8 años. Apolonia es casada, tiene 54 años y 6 hijos D. los cuales 2 viven con ella, Apolonia venD. golosinas D. manera ambulatoria en una calle céntrica D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho cerca D. un colegio D. menores. Sus ventas lo realiza en una carretilla.

Apolonia necesita un préstamo D. 2000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra D. galletas, caramelos, chicles, chocolates y parte del préstamo para los gastos D. educación D. su hija.

Sus ahorros lo utilizara en alguna emergencia y los sueños D. Apolonia son que sus ventas mejoren, que sus hijos estudien y sean profesionales.

loans.use: Buy products for resale.

loans.name: Las Rosas De Anco Group

texts.en:
“Las Rosas D. Anco” is a small rural community bank of FINCA Peru’s Wari-project which provides its credit with education services in the rural areas of Huancavelica. Huancavelica is considered one of the poorest regions of Peru and has many limitations being a very mountainous area (altituD. ranges from 2,000 – 5,000 meters above sea level). These limitations incluD. the cold, the difficulty to grow crops, and the lack of an adequate infrastructure of roads and communication systems.

BCR “Las Rosas D. Anco”, is located at approximately 2,300 meters above sea level in the community of Anco, in the district with the same name, province of Churcampa. Anco is located at the border of the Mantaro river and is one of the lowest places in the department of Huancavelica. Due to its relatively low altituD., the area has a warm, almost tropical climate. The warm climate and the vicinity of the river make the area very suitable for growing fruits like oranges, lemons, avocado, papaya and mango. Besides the fruits, most of the people dedicate their time raising guinea-pigs and chicken. They also produce alfalfa, the crop that makes the diet of the guinea-pigs. The town of Anco is situated on the main road between 2 prominent Andes cities: Ayacucho and Huancayo. Business is done with both cities, and also people stopping on the road use the variety of services in town.

Currently the bank is starting its first loan cycle with 10 female borrowers and a total loan of 4,800 soles (about 1,750 US$). The loans range from 200, 300, 400, 500 and up to 600 soles. Because the bank has been formed recently, it has no history yet. The expectations working with FINCA Peru are very clear: increase business and save. For all members, the main use of the savings they will be generating now is for investing in their businesses or for the education of their children, whether to buy school uniforms, supplies, books, or even to pay the fees for entering primary or secondary school.

One of the members of the community bank is Flor D. María Q. A.. Flor will receive a loan of 600 soles and has a small business selling food in a kiosk on the main road. Besides that she also raises guinea-pigs. She almost has 200, and business is going well. Her dream for the future is to have her own restaurant, to have a guinea-pig farm with more than 1,000 small animals, and for her children to study. With her savings, she hopes to open her restaurant and maybe go to a bigger place with her husband, somewhere where there is a university where their children can study, where it will be more easy to have a better business. In FINCA Peru, she wants to learn and save more and learn to valuate herself as a person.

Doris Sara M. P. tells another story. She runs a small grocery store and has an internet cabin. Besides that, she serves meals to the employees of the district government. In the future, she wants to improve her grocery store and send her children to study at the university, so they can be professionals. She would like to improve the number of computers. With her 300 soles loan, she will increase her groceries. Now that she will be working with FINCA Peru, she hopes to save more and to work more responsibly to be able to pay for her loan. She will use her savings to reinvest in her business, increasing her internet business, install a fax machine, and open her restaurant. Now that she is in FINCA Perú, she hopes to to care for and value herself. Most women do not value themselves a lot. Fortunately now there is FINCA Perú which works only with women. She expects to receive trainings on how to improve business and how to work equally with men. (Her husband will do the cooking while she will attend the bank reunion and afterwards she will explain to him what she has learned!).

Tabita Durcal C. A. has a small business selling an elixir of 7 seeds and is running a small grocery store. Besides that she buys and sells cereals and school supplies for the children. With her 400 soles loan, she will buy more supplies for her store. Tabita has many dreams, like improving the lives of her children. When her husband left her, she thought that she would never improve her life and get out of her misery. FINCA Perú, an institution, has come to help the women of the community and help her to be reborn and run her business. With her savings she wants to buy herself her own house and not rent anymore. In FINCA Peru, in her community bank, she hopes to find a new family that will support each other.

loans.use: Buy new supplies

loans.name: Satemi

texts.id:
Satemi, 40 years old, immigrant from Java island. Satemi and husband have lived in Bali for 5 years. This were done since they like to increase family well being. In Java the population is very crowded, and very difficult to open a business. Now they live in a simple rental house with their 2 children. Her husband's occupation is collecting firewood for resale. He already has steady customers, so that he is not worry to market it. To help family income, Satemi opens a foodstall in their house. Satemi also has steady customers, since in the area a plenty of brick making businesses. During rest hours, Satemi's food stall is visited by many customers. To increase business, Satemi hopes to get the Rp 1,000,000 (about US$125) loan. That loan would be used to buy glass rack from stainless steel for Rp500,000 (about $63), so that it would be more hygienic and looks more attractive, since today she is still using wooden rack. The rest of the loan would be used to increase the food stall assortments. Today Satemi could profit Rp25,000 (about $3)/day, and Satemi hopes with the change and additions in her food stall she could increase her profit.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Satemi, 40 tahun, seorang pendatang dari Jawa. Satemi bersama suaminya sudah tinggal di Bali selama 5 tahun. Hal itu dilakukannya karena ia ingin meningkatkan kesejahteraan keluarganya. Di Jawa penduduknya sangat padat dan sangat sulit untuk membuka usaha. Sekarang mereka tinggal disebuah rumah sederhana dengan lahan sewaan bersama 2 orang anaknya. Suaminya bekerja sebagai seorang pencari kayu bakar untuk dijual kembali. Dia sudah mempunyai langganan tetap sehingga pemasarannya tidak perlu dikhawatirkan. Untuk menunjang usaha keluarga, Satemi membuka usaha warung dirumahnya. Satemi juga mempunyai pelanggan tetap, karena disekitar lingkungan tempat tinggalnya banyak terdapat usaha pembuatan batu bata. Sehingga saat jam – jam istirahat siang, warung Satemi banyak dikunjungi pelanggan. Untuk meningkatkan pendapatan warungnya, Satemi mengharapkan untuk mendapat pinjaman sebesar Rp. 1.000.000.- Pinjaman itu akan digunakannya untuk membeli sebuah rak kaca dari bahan stainless seharga Rp. 500.000.- sehingga kelihatan lebih menarik dan hygienis, karena yang sekarang masih dari rak kayu. Sisa dari pinjaman itu akan digunakannya untuk menambah kelengkapan warungnya. Saat ini Satemi bisa memperoleh keuntungan sebesar Rp. 25.000.- per hari dan Satemi berharap dengan adanya perubahan dan penambahan kelengkapan di warungnya, ia bisa meningkatkan keuntungan yang didapatnya.

loans.use: To buy glass rack and add sales items (Membeli rak kaca dan menambah barang dagangan)

loans.name: Jamshed

texts.en:
Jamshed G. is 33 years old. He and his wife have 2 children. Jamshed’s children are small now, but he already is working hard to ensure the best future for them. Jamshed is the only breadwinner in the family and he is really hard-working.

Jamshed has a shop in the central market of Istaravshan. For more than 3 years he has sold soft drinks from this location. Jamshed offers a wide range of soft drinks at attractive prices. His shop is very popular in his neighborhood and brings in a steady income. Jamshed is asking for a loan of 3200 somoni (925 $ US dollars) to expand his inventory. The loan will be repaid in 12 months.

Your support will really help him. Let’s get behind this dedicated father and help him with make his children’s dreams a reality.

loans.use: To buy soft drinks for resale

loans.name: Nasrulloeva

texts.ru:
H. is 37 years old, married and has two children. Her husband works as a doctor in the town hospital. H. has been selling on the market Panshabe in the town of Khudjand for the past 10 years. She sells things like socks, undergarments, towels. She needs a loan to increase commodity circulation on her merchandise.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Хафиза женщина в возрасте 37 лет, замужем имеет 2 детей муж работает мед врачем в городской больнице. Хафиза уже 10 лет как торгует на рынке Панш анбе, гор.Худжанда.Она продает, носки, нижнее белье, полотенца.Для увеличения оборота она решила взять кредит.

loans.use: Increase commodity circulation

loans.name: Azra's Group

texts.en:
Azra B., wife of Mr. M., is a mother of two children: one daughter and one son. Azra’s son is 14 years old and her daughter is 10 years old. She successfully completed her first loan from Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan. Her husband runs a grocery shop, and she would like to apply for a loan to expand into a bigger grocery store.

Her loan group includes: Rashida B., who wants to purchase and sell tape recorders; Bashiran B., who wants to buy horse; Sharifan B. who wants to start a milk business; and Balqees B., who wants to buy buffalo. This is loan will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Safia's Group

texts.en:
Safia F., wife of Mr. F., is a mother of three children: two daughters and one son. Their eldest daughter, Sehar, 12 years old, is in fifth grade. Their second daughter, Maryam is 10 years old and she is in fourth grade. Their son is nine months old. Safia has a dream to see her children secure their future goals. Her husband has a motorbike rental business. Her daily income is $6 to $7. She applies would like to apply for a loan to buy a motorbike to increase the rental business.

Her loan group members include: Zubaida B., who wants to expand her bakery business; Rehana B. who wants to expand her milk business; Mafia B. who wants to expand her tape recorder business; and Noor B. who wants to expand her motorbike rental business. This is loan will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: Expand their businesses on large scale
